questions.text: Which of the following statements is false on the first-degree atrioventricular (AV) block?

options.label: A
options.text: Delayed conduction through the AV node

questions.explanation:
First-degree atrioventricular (AV) block

Definition

Delayed conduction through the AV node, (Option A ruled out) resulting in a prolonged PR interval (> 0.20 seconds but < 0.50 seconds) (Option B)

Symptoms

Rarely symptomatic; often found incidentally on ECG.

Causes
  • Physiological (e.g., in athletes with high vagal tone) (Option C)
  • May indicate underlying heart disease.

ECG Findings

Prolonged (> 0.20 seconds but < 0.50 seconds) but consistent PR interval (Option D)

Management

No treatment required in most cases

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with no history of myocardial infarction presents with syncope and is found to have a 2:1 AV block on his ECG. His QRS complex is widened. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism behind his AV block, and how would atropine administration affect his condition?

options.label: A
options.text: The block is most likely in the AV node, and atropine will improve AV conduction.

options.label: B
options.text: The block is most likely in the His-Purkinje system, and atropine will improve AV conduction.

options.label: C
options.text: The block is most likely in the AV node, and atropine may increase the degree of AV block.

options.label: D
options.text: The block is most likely in the His-Purkinje system, and atropine may increase the degree of AV block.

questions.correct_answer: D. The block is most likely in the His-Purkinje system, and atropine may increase the degree of AV block.

questions.text: Which among the following are included in the criteria for Metabolic syndrome 1) Waist circumference > 102 cm in men 2) Waist circumference > 88cm in women 3) HDL < 50 mg/dL in men 4) BP >128/88 mm hg 5) Fasting plasma glucose > 100 mg/dL 6) LDL > 200 mg/dL
questions.explanation:
1) Waist circumference
  • > 102 cm in Men
  • > 88 cmin Women

2) HDL levels
  • < 40 mg/dL in Men
  • < 50 mg/dL in Women

3) Triglyceride levels
  • > 150 mg/dL

4) BP (Blood Pressure)
  • > 130/85 mmHg

5) Fasting plasma glucose
  • > 100 mg/dL

questions.text: All of the following are first-line drugs used in the treatment of chronic heart failure, except
questions.explanation:
First-line drugs used in the treatment of Chronic CHF (mortality-reducing)

ARBs/ACE-inhibitors/ARNI
  • Either of these can be started as initial therapy.
  • ACE-inhibitors: Captopril, Enalapril
  • ARBs: Telmisartan, Olmesartan (Option A ruled out)
  • ARNI: ARB+Neprilysin inhibitor - Valsartan-Sacubitril (most preferred 1st line drug)
  • ADR of ACE-i: Cough, angioedema

Beta-blockers
  • Cardioselective (2nd gen): Metoprolol, Bisoprolol
  • 3rd gen: Carvedilol (both α- & β- blocking action) - Best beta blocker for heart failure (Option B ruled out)
  • ADR: Bradycardia, Hypotension

SGLT-2 Inhibitors
  • Dapagliflozin, Empagliflozin
  • ADR: UTI, Forunier gangrene, Euglycemic DKA

Aldosterone antagonists
  • Spironolactone (Option C ruled out)
  • ADR: Gynaecomastia

questions.text: A patient presents with sudden onset breathlessness. On arrival his vitals were, PR- 130 bpm, BP- 180/90 mmHg and spO2- 82% in room air. X-ray done is as shown below. Airway was secured after which his saturation improved. What is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Reassure and monitor vitals of this patient

questions.explanation:
First line drugs used in chronic Heart failure: (mortality-reducing drugs)
  • ARBs/ACE-Inhibitors
  • Beta blockers (2nd gen- cardioselective)
  • SGLT-2 inhibitors (Dapagliflozin, Empagliflozin)
  • Anti-aldosterone (Spironolactone)

Acute cases with Pulmonary edema:
  • Oxygen: Secure airway and supplement O2
  • Loop diuretics: IV Furosemide 20-80 mg, reduces preload and systemic venous congestion
  • IV Morphine: if patient is in severe pain/distress, can cause respiratory depression
  • IV Nitroglycerin infusion: reduce afterload

Acute decompensated with cardiogenic shock: (low BP)
  • Vasopressors: Norepinephrine, Dobutamine, Dopamine
  • Inodilators: Milrinone & Amrinone
  • Levosimendan: Ca2+ channel sensitizer
  • Omecamtiv mecarbil: Direct myosin activator

Non-pharmacological treatment:
  • Implantable cardioverter defibrillators (ICD)
  • Coronary revascularisation: in Coronary artery disease patients
  • Ventricular assist devices
  • Cardiac transplantation

questions.text: A patient, known case of Coronary artery disease presented with fatigue. Echocardiography done showed reduced ejection fraction. What could be the most likely electrolyte disturbance seen in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Serum
  • Elevated BNP/N-terminal pro-BNP levels (BNP- Brain Natriuretic Peptide)
  • Hyponatremia (Water retention - dilutional hypoNa+)
  • Hypokalemia (RAAS activation)
  • Hyperaldosteronism
  • Renal function tests: Urea, Creatinine (Renal failure can occur as a complication)

Radiological findings
  • Earliest: Prominent upper lobe pulmonary veins (Antral sign/ Reverse-Mustache sign)
  • Batwing-shaped opacities - pulmonary edema
  • Costophrenic angle blunting
  • Kerley B lines: Horizontal lines in costophrenic angle perpendicular to the pleural surface.

Echocardio- graphy
  • Reduced ejection fraction: seen in systolic dysfunction (HFrEF)
  • Normal to mildly reduced EF: seen in diastolic dysfunction (HFpEF)

Cardiac MRI
  • Preferred imaging modality to differentiate systolic and diastolic dysfunction.
  • Used for prognosis.

Investigations for congestive heart failure

Serum
  • BNP/N-terminal pro-BNP levels ↑
  • Serum Na+, K+ ↓
  • Hyperaldosteronism
  • Renal function tests: Renal failure can occur as a complication

Radiological findings
  • Earliest: Antral sign/ Reverse-Mustache sign
  • Batwing shaped opacities
  • Costophrenic angle blunting
  • Kerley B lines

Echocardio- graphy
  • Reduced ejection fraction: seen in systolic dysfunction
  • Normal to mildly reduced EF: seen in diastolic dysfunction

Cardiac MRI
  • Differentiate systolic and diastolic dysfunction.
  • Used for prognosis.

questions.text: A 50 year old male gives a history of fatigue and dyspnoea upon lying down for 1 week. On examination, his vitals were: HR-130 bpm, BP-150/90 mmHg, S3+ on auscultation. Chest X-ray is as shown in the image below. Which among the following in this patient is not part of the major criterion according to Framingham’s?
questions.explanation:
Major criteria

Minor criteria
  • Acute pulmonary edema (crepitations/rales)
  • Cardiomegaly (Option B)
  • PND/Orthopnoea (Option A)
  • Elevated JVP, Abdominojugular reflex
  • S3 gallop rhythm + (Option D)
  • Ankle edema (pitting pedal edema)
  • Dyspnoea on exertion
  • Tender hepatomegaly
  • Nocturnal cough
  • Pleural effusion
  • Tachycardia (HR>120 bpm) (Option C)

Stage A
  • Only risk factors - Hypertension, DM, Atherosclerosis, Obesity, etc. present
  • NO structural damage

Stage B
  • Structural heart disease is present (e.g., LVH, dysmotility on ECHO, etc.)
  • NO signs/symptoms seen

Stage C
  • Most common clinical stage
  • Signs/symptoms seen pertaining to CHF

Stage D
  • No response to any medical therapy - known as Refractory heart failure
  • Only treatment is Cardiac transplant

questions.text: A 68-year-old male is presenting with sudden loss of consciousness and collapse. He had pallor during the attack. ECG is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Third-degree atrioventricular block

Definition

Complete failure of conduction between atria and ventricles, resulting in independent beating (AV dissociation).

Ventricular Activity

Maintained by an escape rhythm from:

- The AV node or bundle of His (narrow QRS complexes).

- Distal Purkinje tissues (broad QRS complexes).

Clinical Features

- Recurrent syncope or 'Stokes–Adams' attacks- sudden loss of consciousness and collapse.

- Brief anoxic seizure.

- Pallor and a death-like appearance during the attack; characteristic flush upon recovery.

- Rapid recovery distinguishes it from epilepsy.

Management

- Depends on clinical circumstances.

- Transient AV block in acute inferior myocardial infarction- no treatment if the patient remains stable.

- Symptomatic third-degree AV block- intravenous atropine or intravenous isoprenaline to maintain circulation until temporary pacing is inserted.

- Permanent pacemaker.

questions.text: Identify the type of heart block from the ECG given below.
questions.explanation:
Second-degree heart block

Dropped beats occur because some impulses from the atria fail to be transmitted to the ventricles.

Types

Mobitz Type I (Wenckebach) (Option B)

Mobitz Type II (Option C)

Description
  • Progressive lengthening of PR intervals until a dropped beat occurs.
  • Cycle repeats itself.
  • PR interval remains constant.
  • Some P waves are not conducted.

Clinical Features
  • Often physiological; can occur in young athletes.
  • May not cause symptoms.
  • Caused by His–Purkinje system disease.
  • Higher risk of asystole.

Management
  • Typically does not require treatment.
  • Monitor for changes; consider underlying heart disease.
  • May require treatment if symptomatic.
  • Consider temporary pacing.
  • Monitor closely due to the risk of progression.

questions.text: A 68-year-old patient with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents with palpitations and shortness of breath. The ECG is given below and has an irregular rhythm with at least three distinct P-wave morphologies. The heart rate is 120 beats per minute. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the ECG findings?
questions.explanation:
Multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT)

ECG Characteristics
  • At least three distinct P-wave morphologies
  • Atrial rates typically between 100-150 bpm.
  • Clear isoelectric intervals between P waves (unlike atrial fibrillation)
  • Atrial rate slower than atrial fibrillation

Mechanism

Caused by automaticity from multiple atrial foci, with multiple areas in the atria spontaneously generating electrical impulses.

Common Causes
  • Chronic pulmonary disease
  • Acute illness

questions.text: Which of the following statements on transvenous pacing is wrong?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Transcutaneous Pacing

Transvenous Pacing

Purpose

Temporary, fast initiation for symptomatic bradyarrhythmias or cardiac arrest.

Longer-term temporary pacing for evaluation of permanent pacemaker need. (Option C)

Initiation Time

Fastest method, used in emergencies (e.g., bradycardia, asystole).

Requires more time due to the need for central venous access. (Option A and Option D)

Electrode Placement

Anterior pad: cardiac apex or lead V3 position.

Posterior pad: inferior to scapula or between scapula and spine.


 

Intracardiac lead placement through a central vein (e.g., femoral, subclavian). (Option B ruled out)

questions.text: A 72-year-old male presents with dizziness. His heart rate is 38 bpm, blood pressure 80/50 mmHg, and ECG confirms sinus bradycardia. What is the medication to be used?
questions.correct_answer: A. IV atropine 0.5 mg every 3-5 minutes
questions.explanation:
Sinus bradycardia

Definition

Sinus bradycardia is a cardiac rhythm with normal sinus node depolarization but a rate < 60 bpm.

Diagnostic Criteria

ECG showing sinus rhythm at a rate lower than 60 bpm.

Common Etiologies
  • Normal in athletes
  • Medications (beta-blockers, calcium channel blockers, digoxin)
  • Hypothyroidism, hypothermia
  • Sick sinus syndrome, myocardial infarction
  • Vagal stimulation (e.g., vasovagal syncope)

Clinical Features
  • Asymptomatic (in many patients)
  • Fatigue
  • Dizziness or lightheadedness
  • Exercise intolerance
  • Syncope or presyncope
  • Cognitive slowing
  • Worsening angina or heart failure symptoms

Evaluation
  • Assess hemodynamic stability
  • ECG to confirm sinus rhythm
  • Review medication list for bradycardic agents
  • Evaluate for comorbidities (e.g., hypothyroidism, myocardial infarction)

Management
  • If Hemodynamically Unstable:
    • IV atropine 0.5 mg every 3-5 minutes (max 3 mg) (Option A)
    • If there is no improvement, consider a temporary pacemaker
  • If Stable:
    • Treat underlying causes
    • Withdraw bradycardia-inducing medications
    • Evaluate for permanent pacemaker

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with a history of hypertension and coronary artery disease presents to the emergency department with worsening shortness of breath over the past 3 days. His blood pressure is 160/90 mmHg, and he has bilateral pitting edema in his lower extremities. Lung auscultation reveals crackles at the bases. His chest X-ray shows cardiomegaly and pulmonary congestion. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism contributing to his symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Clinical Features of Left-Sided vs. Right-Sided Congestive Heart Failure (CHF)

Left-Sided Heart Failure

Right-Sided Heart Failure

Causes:

  • Ischemic heart disease (myocardial infarction).
  • Hypertension
  • Dilated cardiomyopathy.
  • Aortic or mitral valve disease.

Causes:

  • Left-sided heart failure (most common cause).
  • Chronic lung diseases (COPD, pulmonary hypertension).
  • Pulmonary embolism.
  • Right ventricular infarction.

In left-sided heart failure, the left ventricle cannot effectively pump blood to the body, leading to a backup of blood into the lungs.

 

Clinical features:

This primarily results in pulmonary symptoms.

  • Dyspnea
  • Exertional dyspnea).
  • Orthopnea
  • Paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea

 

Pulmonary Congestion:

  • Crackles (rales) heard on auscultation due to fluid in the alveoli.
  • Cough
  • Wheezing (cardiac asthma).
 
  • Fatigue and Weakness
  • Decreased Exercise Tolerance
  • Limited physical activity due to breathlessness and fatigue.
  • S3 Gallop

 

  • Cool Extremities: Reduced cardiac output may cause poor peripheral circulation, leading to cold, pale skin.

In right-sided heart failure, the right ventricle fails to pump blood effectively into the pulmonary circulation, leading to systemic venous congestion. It is often secondary to left-sided heart failure or conditions affecting the lungs (cor pulmonale).

 

Clinical Features:

  • Peripheral Edema
  • Jugular Venous Distension (JVD)
  • Hepatomegaly
  • B/L pitting pedal edema
  • Kussmaul sign: JVP elevation on inspiration
  • Ascites
  • Nocturia
  • Weight Gain
  • Anorexia and Nausea

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents to the emergency department with complaints of palpitations and dizziness over the past week. He denies any chest pain or syncope. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the ECG findings?
questions.explanation:
Description
  • Right bundle branch block (RBBB) is an electrocardiogram finding that occurs when the physiologic electrical conduction system of the heart, specifically in the His-Purkinje system, is altered or interrupted resulting in a widened QRS and electrocardiographic vector changes

Etiopathogenesis

Structural Heart Disease:

  • Coronary Artery Disease (CAD)
  • Heart Failure
  • Valvular Heart Disease: Aortic stenosis or regurgitation, mitral stenosis, or regurgitation, leading to right heart strain and RBBB.
  • Cardiomyopathies: Dilated or hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.
 

Pulmonary Causes:

  • Pulmonary Embolism (PE): Large emboli can cause acute right heart strain, leading to RBBB.
  • Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)
  • Pulmonary Hypertension
 

Infiltrative Diseases:

  • Amyloidosis
  • Sarcoidosis
 
  • Due to the anatomy of the right bundle branch, damage typically occurs at 3 different locations.
  • The proximal right bundle nearest the endocardium is the most common location to be affected.
  • The distal right bundle is typically only injured when the moderator band is transected during surgery.
  • The terminal right bundle is injured during ventriculotomy or transatrial resectio

Clinical features
  • Often asymptomatic and found incidentally.
  • In some cases, patients may experience palpitations, dizziness, or lightheadedness.
  • When associated with other cardiac pathology (heart failure, ischemia), it may indicate an underlying issue.
  • Wide split S2 heart sound heard.

Diagnosis

The characteristic ECG findings for right bundle branch block are as follows:

  • QRS duration is greater than or equal to 120 milliseconds.
  • In lead V1 and V2, there is an RSR` in leads V1 and V2.
  • In Leads 1 and V6, the S wave is of greater duration than the R wave, or the S wave is greater than 40 milliseconds.
  • In Leads V5 and V6, there is a normal R wave peak time.
  • In Lead V1, the R wave peak time is greater than 50 milliseconds.

Differential Diagnosis
  • Brugada syndrome
  • Ventricular tachycardia
  • Incomplete left bundle branch block

Treatment
  • No specific treatment is required for asymptomatic isolated RBBB.
  • Management focuses on treating underlying conditions (if present).

ECG difference between LBBB and RBBB

LBBB

RBBB

WiLLiaM - W pattern in V1 and M pattern in V6

MaRRoW - M pattern in V1 and W pattern in V6

questions.text: A 70-year-old male with a history of chronic hypertension and known Left Bundle Branch Block (LBBB) presents to the emergency department with acute chest pain radiating to the left arm. His ECG shows a wide QRS complex due to LBBB. You are concerned about a possible myocardial infarction (MI), and consider using the Sgarbossa criteria. Which of the following findings would be consistent with a positive Sgarbossa criterion for acute myocardial infarction?

options.label: A
options.text: Concordant ST elevation ≥ 1 mm in leads with a positive QRS complex

options.label: B
options.text: Discordant ST elevation ≥ 1 mm in leads with a negative QRS complex

options.label: C
options.text: Concordant ST elevation ≥ 1 mm in any anterior lead (V1-V3)

options.label: D
options.text: Discordant ST depression ≥ 1 mm in any lead

questions.correct_answer: A. Concordant ST elevation ≥ 1 mm in leads with a positive QRS complex
questions.explanation:
Sgarbossa criteria

Used to diagnose acute myocardial infarction (AMI) in the presence of a Left Bundle Branch Block (LBBB) or ventricular-paced rhythm, where typical ECG changes of MI may be obscured by the abnormal conduction pattern.

Criteria

1. Concordant ST elevation ≥ 1 mm in any lead with a positive QRS complex (QRS and ST segment in the same direction).

  • Score: 5 points
  • This finding is highly specific for acute MI.
 

2. Concordant ST depression ≥ 1 mm in leads V1, V2, or V3 (with a negative QRS complex).

  • Score: 3 points
  • ST depression in these leads suggests posterior infarction.
 

3. Discordant ST elevation (ST elevation ≥ 5 mm) in leads with a negative QRS complex (QRS and ST segment in opposite directions).

  • Score: 2 points


 

Modified Sgarbossa Criteria
  • A modification to the original criteria uses a ST/S ratio in discordant leads.
  • ST elevation must be ≥ 25% of the depth of the preceding S wave in leads with a negative QRS complex (instead of ≥ 5 mm).

Interpretation

A total score of ≥ 3 points is considered suggestive of acute MI in the setting of LBBB.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with complaints of occasional chest discomfort and shortness of breath on exertion.His medical history includes hypertension and diabetes. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the ECG findings?
questions.explanation:
Description
  • Left bundle branch block (LBBB) is an intraventricular conduction abnormality usually caused by ischemic or mechanical factors affecting the cardiac conduction system's left bundle branch.

Etiology
  • Structural heart disease: Coronary artery disease (CAD), hypertension, cardiomyopathies such as dilated, left ventricular noncompaction, stress, and hypertrophic cardiomyopathies, and aortic valve diseases like aortic stenosis and regurgitation
  • Degenerative changes: Age-related fibrosis, Lev disease, and Lenègre disease
  • Infiltrative conditions: sarcoidosis or amyloidosis
  • Inflammatory cardiomyopathies: Infectious myocarditis or autoimmune disease
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Antiarrhythmic medications

Pathogenesis
  • Electrical Dyssynchrony: With LBBB, the right ventricle is activated first, followed by a right-to-left septal transmission and activation of the left ventricular endocardium at the level of the mid septum.
  • Mechanical Dyssynchrony: In LBBB, the septum is activated before aortic valve opening (isovolumetric contraction), stretching the posterior and lateral walls

Clinical features
  • LBBB may be silent, especially in its early stages, or present with nonspecific symptoms, such as fatigue, dyspnea, and palpitations.
  • Symptoms due to underlying heart disease can include chest pain, dyspnea, fatigue, palpitations, syncope, or presyncope.

Diagnosis

ECG findings

  • QRS duration greater than or equal to 120 ms.
  • Broad notched or slurred R wave in leads I, aVL, V5, and V6 or, occasionally, an RS pattern in leads V5 and V6.
  • Absence of Q wave in leads I, V5, and V6 (with the possible exception of aVL).
  • R wave peak time greater than 60 ms in leads V5 and V6.
  • ST-T waves change opposite to the QRS direction.

  • Echocardiography
  • Stress Imaging
  • Electrophysiological studies

Differential Diagnosis
  • Incomplete Left Bundle Branch Block
  • Ventricular Paced Rhythm
  • Left Ventricular Hypertrophy
  • Premature Ventricular Contractions

Treatment
  • Asymptomatic Patients: No specific treatment is required if LBBB is discovered incidentally and the patient has no symptoms or associated conditions (coronary artery disease, heart failure).
  • Symptomatic Patients: If LBBB is associated with coronary artery disease, hypertension, or heart failure, these conditions should be managed according to standard treatment guidelines.
  • Cardiac Resynchronization Therapy (CRT): Indicated in patients with heart failure and reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF).
  • Immediate reperfusion therapy: Indicated in patients with AMI and LBBB.

questions.text: What is the heart rate if there are 5 large boxes between R waves on an ECG?
questions.explanation:
P wave
  • It represents atrial depolarization on the ECG. As atrial depolarization is initiated by the SA node located in the right atrium, the right atrium gets depolarized first, followed by left atrial depolarization.
  • Its duration is three small squares wide and 2.5 small squares high.

PR Interval
  • It represents the time from the beginning of atrial depolarization to the start of ventricular depolarization and includes the delay at the AV node.
  • The average interval is 3 to 5 small squares (120 to 200 ms).

QRS complex
  • It represents ventricular depolarization as current passes down the AV node.
  • A standard QRS complex has a duration of less than three small squares (under 120 ms, usually 60 to 100 ms).

Septal Q-Wave
  • Represents the depolarization of the interventricular septum.
  • Its amplitude is not bigger than 0.1 mV,

R-Wave
  • It is the tallest wave of the QRS complex, representing the electrical stimulus as it passes down the ventricles during depolarization.

S-Wave
  • It represents the final depolarization of the Purkinje fibers.
  • It is any downward deflection after R-wave.

T-Wave
  • It represents ventricular repolarization.
  • The suggested criteria for the typical T wave include the size of one-eighth or less than two-thirds of the size of the R wave and a height of less than 10 mm.

ST-Segment
  • It depicts the end of ventricular depolarization and the beginning of ventricular repolarization.
  • The average duration of the ST segment is less than 2 to 3 small squares (80-120 ms).

QT-Interval
  • It represents the start of depolarization to the end of the repolarization of ventricles.
  • Generally, the normal QT interval is less than 400 to 440 milliseconds (ms), or 0.4 to 0.44 seconds.

U-Wave
  • Small wave that follows the T wave.
  • It represents the delayed repolarization of the papillary muscles or Purkinje fibers.
  • It is commonly associated with hypokalemia.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents to the ER with palpitations and shortness of breath. His ECG shows an irregular rhythm with at least three distinct P-wave morphologies and a heart rate of 120 beats per minute. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management approach for this patient?

options.label: C
options.text: Correcting underlying metabolic abnormalities and treating the underlying lung disease

questions.correct_answer: C. Correcting underlying metabolic abnormalities and treating the underlying lung disease
questions.explanation:
Multifocal atrial tachycardia

ECG Characteristics
  • At least three distinct P-wave morphologies
  • Atrial rates typically between 100-150 bpm.
  • Clear isoelectric intervals between P waves (unlike atrial fibrillation)
  • Atrial rate slower than atrial fibrillation

Mechanism

Caused by automaticity from multiple atrial foci, with multiple areas in the atria spontaneously generating electrical impulses.

Common Causes
  • Chronic pulmonary disease
  • Acute illness

Treatment Approaches
  • Treat underlying disease: Most important step.
  • Correct metabolic abnormalities: Address electrolyte imbalances.
  • Calcium channel blockers: Verapamil or diltiazem to slow atrial and ventricular rate.
  • Amiodarone: Can be effective but avoided long-term due to potential toxicities (e.g., pulmonary fibrosis). (Option D ruled out)

Thromboembolism Risk

Not as well-defined or high as in atrial fibrillation or flutter.
